importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The Ostwall complex was abandoned by the Nazis in 1945, marking the end of its military use and the beginning of its postwar transformation.
The London Tunnels are expected to open to the public in 2028 as a major new tourist attraction, signaling a shift in public interest in Cold War-era underground history.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The Ostwall complex was constructed during the 1930s–1940s by Nazi Germany for military use, placing it within the context of World War II and Nazi engineering efforts.
The London Tunnels were built during World War II and have since been preserved and restored, with a planned public opening in 2028 to serve as a modern cultural and historical destination.

keyTakeAways: The Ostwall underground complex in Poland was built by Nazi Germany as a fortified military city and is now a dark tourism site managed by the Międzyrzecz Fortified Region Museum.

The Ostwall was abandoned in 1945 and later inhabited by the 'Bunker People' in the 1980s and 1990s, who hosted dangerous underground events, before being reclaimed by bats, now numbering about 40,000.
A 19-mile section of the Ostwall tunnels is open to the public as a tourist attraction, offering visitors an experience into wartime military engineering and postwar subterranean culture.
The Passage of Commodus in Rome, a 180-foot tunnel from ancient times, is being opened to the public and is believed to have been used by Emperor Commodus to evade assassination attempts.

The London Tunnels, built during WWII for civil defense, are being transformed into a $149 million tourist attraction and are expected to open in 2028, drawing inspiration from the real-life James Bond Q Branch.
Kayaköy in Turkey, once a thriving town, is now a ghost town abandoned after the Greco-Turkish war, serving as a haunting reminder of historical displacement and loss.

Babylon in modern Iraq, once a central city of antiquity, now faces deterioration due to environmental and structural neglect, yet still retains its historical grandeur and draws visitors to its ruins.

The West Virginia Trans-Allegheny Lunatic Asylum, now a tourist site, was originally a compassionate institution that became overcrowded, leading to tragic outcomes and now offers a mix of historical education and paranormal experiences.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article explores a range of underground and abandoned sites around the world, from Nazi-built tunnels in Poland to ancient Roman tunnels in Rome and Cold War-era shelters in London. It highlights the Ostwall, a 20-mile Nazi underground complex in Poland abandoned in 1945, which is now a dark tourism destination managed by the Międzyrzecz Fortified Region Museum. The article also covers the Passage of Commodus in Rome, believed to have been used by Emperor Commodus to avoid assassination, and the London Tunnels, a Cold War shelter now undergoing a $149 million transformation to become a major tourist attraction. Additional sites include the ghost town of Kayaköy in Turkey and the ancient ruins of Babylon in Iraq, all serving as powerful reminders of human history, conflict, and resilience. The piece underscores how historical sites, once sites of danger or suffering, are now being repurposed as educational and experiential tourist destinations.
title: Deep underground, the Nazis built a city for thousands of soldiers. Now it’s a tourist attraction
